text:
- Our mission is to make
the world a more just place.
It is also to make the law more accessible
and available to others.
And in order to do that,
you have to highlight the connections.

LexisNexis has about five
petabytes of legal data

that it collects from
50,000 different sources
around the world.
One of our primary challenges is

how to take that text-based
data that we collect
from law firms and courts
and convert that into usable information

for lawyers to use and make
decisions for their clients.
And so we engaged with AWS

and our AWS business partners
to try to get that data
from the 29 different data centers
that we had into a cloud repository.

And then from there, we
could start to leverage

some of the cool tools that
help us mine that data.

Before Amazon Neptune, we
used to keep our connections
in a relational database.
And anytime we had to make a change
in a citation or a reference,

we'd have to update the
entire database and the index.
This took weeks.
With Amazon Neptune,
because it's a graph database,
we can isolate single connection change
and change just that connection,
and this can be done in seconds.
So it's been a very big advantage for us
in efficiency and cost savings.
